message: a real-time chat app with persistent storage is basically the hello world for node.js
Any great node.js sources for getting started? I dont know what to build yet so idears are welcome as well
@Ezku is there any well-written documented examples of that sort of chat app out there that I could look at?
I just got started with node, I had a go at building a bot for here
You can visit @karmabot, he's currently hanging out with @evilbot in https://convore.com/evilbot/evilbot/
@evilbot is also written for nodejs, but via coffeescript, the source is available on @defunkt 's github

Here's my list of resources for getting started:
http://dailyjs.com/tags.html#lmawa
http://howtonode.org/
http://nodetuts.com/
http://camp.nodejs.org/videos/session-04_tim_caswell.html
http://camp.nodejs.org/videos/session-01_ryan_dahl.html
http://blog.nodejitsu.com/keep-a-nodejs-server-up-with-forever
http://expressjs.com/
http://npmjs.org/
http://blog.osbutler.com/tags/node-by-example/
http://blog.mixu.net/2010/12/30/learning-node-js-my-experiences-and-helpful-resources/
http://nodejs.org/
http://socket.io/

Ought to be able to glean some useful resources from those.
You have to be aware when you're reading through resources. Since node.js is still young it is constantly changing, so a lot of the time some things have changed since the resource was published.

I've been writing a bit about building a web app from scratch with node.js along with some details about using modules and tools for debugging over on Node Nerd (http://nodenerd.net/About) and made a list similar to, but much less comprehensive than Mixu's here: http://nodenerd.net/post/2498008243/other-node-js-resources
@kevingorski hey man been following your blog, cool stuff :)
I'm getting into js/node still, reading 'the good parts' and stuff in the little time I have free
meaning, I have no idea on which topics one would blog :P
@locks Thanks man! I've been trying to keep it going and make the content at least somewhat interesting as I figure out both technical blogging and node itself.
If there's anything you think I should have more/less of, let me know
I have made a tag about no.de here: http://www.diigo.com/user/shingonoide/no.de. Like it.

Hi all, I've started to work on The Node Beginner Book, a comprehensive guide for experienced developer that are new to JavaScript and node. It's still work in progress, but already usable: http://www.nodebeginner.org/
I'm writing about Node on my blog, http://www.strx.it/category/node-js/
